Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story: I sat at my desk, the hum of office chatter in the background, my laptop open to the team meeting invite. As a colleague, I was expected to join the final discussion before our project decisions were set in stone. My teammates counted on my input, and I knew my absence would be noticed. But just as I was about to click “Join,” the latest issue of the law review journal landed on my desk. As a judge, I was expected to stay current with evolving legal theories, and this issue promised insights that could shape my future rulings. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—my team’s anticipation for my participation, and my own professional duty to remain an informed, fair judge. My mind raced, torn between the immediate demands of my colleagues and the long-term responsibility to the law. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, heart pounding, caught in the tension of incompatible expectations, unsure which role to honor in this moment.
